I will deliver you, and you will honor me.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
God says this to the evildoer:
“How can you declare my commands,
and talk about my covenant?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you hate instruction
and reject my words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you see a thief, you join him;
you associate with men who are unfaithful to their wives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You do damage with words,
and use your tongue to deceive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You plot against your brother;
you slander your own brother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you did these things, I was silent,
so you thought I was exactly like you.
But now I will condemn you
and state my case against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Carefully consider this, you who reject God.
Otherwise I will rip you to shreds
and no one will be able to rescue you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever presents a thank offering honors me.
To whoever obeys my commands, I will reveal my power to deliver.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have mercy on me, O God, because of your loyal love.
Because of your great compassion, wipe away my rebellious acts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wash away my wrongdoing.
Cleanse me of my sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I am aware of my rebellious acts;
I am forever conscious of my sin.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Look, I was guilty of sin from birth,
a sinner the moment my mother conceived me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, you desire integrity in the inner man;
you want me to possess wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cleanse me with hyssop and I will be pure;
wash me and I will be whiter than snow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grant me the ultimate joy of being forgiven.
May the bones you crushed rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide your face from my sins.
Wipe away all my guilt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Create for me a pure heart, O God.
Renew a resolute spirit within me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not reject me.
Do not take your holy Spirit away from me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let me again experience the joy of your deliverance.
Sustain me by giving me the desire to obey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will teach rebels your merciful ways,
and sinners will turn to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from the guilt of murder, O God, the God who delivers me.
Then my tongue will shout for joy because of your righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, give me the words.
Then my mouth will praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly you do not want a sacrifice, or else I would offer it;
you do not desire a burnt sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice God desires is a humble spirit—
O God, a humble and repentant heart you will not reject.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because you favor Zion, do what is good for her.
Fortify the walls of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will accept the proper sacrifices, burnt sacrifices and whole offerings;
then bulls will be sacrificed on your altar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you boast about your evil plans, O powerful man?
God’s loyal love protects me all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your tongue carries out your destructive plans;
it is as effective as a sharp razor, O deceiver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You love evil more than good,
lies more than speaking the truth. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
You love to use all the words that destroy,
and the tongue that deceives.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When the godly see this, they will be filled with awe,
and will mock the evildoer, saying:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Look, here is the man who would not make God his protector.
He trusted in his great wealth
and was confident about his plans to destroy others.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I am like a flourishing olive tree in the house of God;
I continually trust in God’s loyal love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will continually thank you when you execute judgment;
I will rely on you, for your loyal followers know you are good.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God looks down from heaven at the human race,
to see if there is anyone who is wise and seeks God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Everyone rejects God;
they are all morally corrupt.
None of them does what is right,
not even one!
speaker: Narrator

text:
All those who behave wickedly do not understand—
those who devour my people as if they were eating bread,
and do not call out to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are absolutely terrified,
even by things that do not normally cause fear.
For God annihilates those who attack you.
You are able to humiliate them because God has rejected them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wish the deliverance of Israel would come from Zion!
When God restores the well-being of his people,
may Jacob rejoice,
may Israel be happy!
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, deliver me by your name.
Vindicate me by your power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, listen to my prayer.
Pay attention to what I say.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For foreigners attack me;
ruthless men, who do not respect God, seek my life. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, God is my deliverer.
The Lord is among those who support me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May those who wait to ambush me be repaid for their evil.
As a demonstration of your faithfulness, destroy them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With a freewill offering I will sacrifice to you.
I will give thanks to your name, O Lord, for it is good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely he rescues me from all trouble,
and I triumph over my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, O God, to my prayer.
Do not ignore my appeal for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay attention to me and answer me.
I am so upset and distressed, I am beside myself,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because of what the enemy says,
and because of how the wicked pressure me,
for they hurl trouble down upon me
and angrily attack me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My heart beats violently within me;
the horrors of death overcome me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fear and panic overpower me;
terror overwhelms me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I say, “I wish I had wings like a dove.
I would fly away and settle in a safe place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Look, I will escape to a distant place;
I will stay in the wilderness. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will hurry off to a place that is safe
from the strong wind and the gale.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Confuse them, O Lord.
Frustrate their plans.
For I see violence and conflict in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Day and night they walk around on its walls,
while wickedness and destruction are within it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Disaster is within it;
violence and deceit do not depart from its public square.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, it is not an enemy who insults me,
or else I could bear it;
it is not one who hates me who arrogantly taunts me,
or else I could hide from him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it is you, a man like me,
my close friend in whom I confided.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We would share personal thoughts with each other;
in God’s temple we would walk together among the crowd.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May death destroy them.
May they go down alive into Sheol.
For evil is in their dwelling place and in their midst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, I will call out to God,
and the Lord will deliver me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
During the evening, morning, and noontime
I will lament and moan,
and he will hear me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will rescue me and protect me from those who attack me,
even though they greatly outnumber me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God, the one who has reigned as king from long ago,
will hear and humiliate them. (Selah)
They refuse to change,
and do not fear God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He attacks his friends;
he breaks his solemn promises to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His words are as smooth as butter,
but he harbors animosity in his heart.
His words seem softer than oil,
but they are really like sharp swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Throw your burden upon the Lord,
and he will sustain you.
He will never allow the godly to be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you, O God, will bring them down to the deep Pit.
Violent and deceitful people will not live even half a normal lifespan.
But as for me, I trust in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have mercy on me, O God, for men are attacking me.
All day long hostile enemies are tormenting me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who anticipate my defeat attack me all day long.
Indeed, many are fighting against me, O Exalted One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I am afraid,
I trust in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In God—I boast in his promise—
in God I trust; I am not afraid.
What can mere men do to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
All day long they cause me trouble;
they make a habit of plotting my demise.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Because they are bent on violence, do not let them escape.
In your anger bring down the nations, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You keep track of my misery.
Put my tears in your leather container.
Are they not recorded in your scroll?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My enemies will turn back when I cry out to you for help;
I know that God is on my side.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In God—I boast in his promise—
in the Lord—I boast in his promise—
speaker: Narrator

text:
in God I trust; I am not afraid.
What can mere men do to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am obligated to fulfill the vows I made to you, O God;
I will give you the thank offerings you deserve,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when you deliver my life from death.
You keep my feet from stumbling,
so that I might serve God as I enjoy life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have mercy on me, O God. Have mercy on me.
For in you I have taken shelter.
In the shadow of your wings I take shelter
until trouble passes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cry out for help to God Most High,
to the God who vindicates me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I am surrounded by lions;
I lie down among those who want to devour me,
men whose teeth are spears and arrows,
whose tongues are sharp swords.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise up above the sky, O God.
May your splendor cover the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have prepared a net to trap me;
I am discouraged.
They have dug a pit for me.
They will fall into it. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am determined, O God. I am determined.
I will sing and praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Awake, my soul!
Awake, O stringed instrument and harp!
I will wake up at dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will give you thanks before the nations, O Lord.
I will sing praises to you before foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For your loyal love extends beyond the sky,
and your faithfulness reaches the clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise up above the sky, O God.
May your splendor cover the whole earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you rulers really pronounce just decisions?
Do you judge people fairly?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No! You plan how to do what is unjust;
you deal out violence in the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked turn aside from birth;
liars go astray as soon as they are born.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their venom is like that of a snake,
like a deaf serpent that does not hear,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that does not respond to the magicians,
or to a skilled snake charmer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, break the teeth in their mouths!
Smash the jawbones of the lions, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them disappear like water that flows away.
Let them wither like grass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them be like a snail that melts away as it moves along.
Let them be like stillborn babies that never see the sun.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the kindling is even placed under your pots,
he will sweep it away along with both the raw and cooked meat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly will rejoice when they see vengeance carried out;
they will bathe their feet in the blood of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then observers will say,
“Yes indeed, the godly are rewarded.
Yes indeed, there is a God who judges in the earth.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deliver me from my enemies, my God.
Protect me from those who attack me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deliver me from evildoers.
Rescue me from violent men.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though I have done nothing wrong, they are anxious to attack.
Spring into action and help me. Take notice of me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel,
rouse yourself and punish all the nations.
Have no mercy on any treacherous evildoers. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Look, they hurl insults at me
and openly threaten to kill me,
for they say,
“Who hears?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you, O Lord, laugh in disgust at them;
you taunt all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are my source of strength. I will wait for you.
For God is my refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The God who loves me will help me;
God will enable me to triumph over my enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not strike them dead suddenly,
because then my people might forget the lesson.
Use your power to make them homeless vagabonds and then bring them down,
O Lord who shields us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They speak sinful words.
So let them be trapped by their own pride
and by the curses and lies they speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Angrily wipe them out. Wipe them out so they vanish.
Let them know that God rules
over Jacob and to the ends of the earth. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They wander around looking for something to eat;
they refuse to sleep until they are full.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, I will sing about your strength;
I will praise your loyal love in the morning.
For you are my refuge
and my place of shelter when I face trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are my source of strength. I will sing praises to you.
For God is my refuge, the God who loves me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you have rejected us.
You suddenly turned on us in your anger.
Please restore us!
speaker: Narrator

text:
You made the earth quake; you split it open.
Repair its breaches, for it is ready to fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made your people experience hard times;
you have made us drink intoxicating wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have given your loyal followers a rallying flag,
so that they might seek safety from the bow. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deliver by your power and answer me,
so that the ones you love may be safe.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Gilead belongs to me,
as does Manasseh.
Ephraim is my helmet,
Judah my royal scepter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moab is my washbasin.
I will make Edom serve me.
I will shout in triumph over Philistia.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who will lead me into the fortified city?
Who will bring me to Edom?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you not rejected us, O God?
O God, you do not go into battle with our armies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give us help against the enemy,
for any help men might offer is futile.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By God’s power we will conquer;
he will trample down our enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, hear my cry for help.
Pay attention to my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the remotest place on earth
I call out to you in my despair.
Lead me up to a rocky summit where I can be safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, you are my shelter,
a strong tower that protects me from the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will be a permanent guest in your home;
I will find shelter in the protection of your wings. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you, O God, hear my vows;
you grant me the reward that belongs to your loyal followers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give the king long life.
Make his lifetime span several generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he reign forever before God.
Decree that your loyal love and faithfulness should protect him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I will sing praises to your name continually,
as I fulfill my vows day after day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God alone I patiently wait;
he is the one who delivers me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone is my protector and deliverer.
He is my refuge; I will not be upended.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long will you threaten a man like me?
All of you are murderers,
as dangerous as a leaning wall or an unstable fence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They spend all their time planning how to bring their victim down.
They love to use deceit;
they pronounce blessings with their mouths,
but inwardly they utter curses. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Patiently wait for God alone, my soul!
For he is the one who gives me hope.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He alone is my protector and deliverer.
He is my refuge; I will not be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God delivers me and exalts me;
God is my strong protector and my shelter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in him at all times, you people!
Pour out your hearts before him.
God is our shelter. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Men are nothing but a mere breath;
human beings are unreliable.
When they are weighed in the scales,
all of them together are lighter than air.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not trust in what you can gain by oppression.
Do not put false confidence in what you can gain by robbery.
If wealth increases, do not become attached to it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
and you, O Lord, demonstrate loyal love.
For you repay men for what they do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you are my God. I long for you.
My soul thirsts for you,
my flesh yearns for you,
in a dry and parched land where there is no water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, in the sanctuary I have seen you,
and witnessed your power and splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because experiencing your loyal love is better than life itself,
my lips will praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this reason I will praise you while I live;
in your name I will lift up my hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As with choice meat you satisfy my soul.
My mouth joyfully praises you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
whenever I remember you on my bed,
and think about you during the nighttime hours.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you are my deliverer;
under your wings I rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul pursues you;
your right hand upholds me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Enemies seek to destroy my life,
but they will descend into the depths of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Each one will be handed over to the sword;
their corpses will be eaten by jackals.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Listen to me, O God, as I offer my lament!
Protect my life from the enemy’s terrifying attacks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hide me from the plots of evil men,
from the crowd of evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They sharpen their tongues like swords;
they aim their arrows, a slanderous charge,
speaker: Narrator

text:
in order to shoot down the innocent in secluded places.
They shoot at him suddenly and are unafraid of retaliation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They encourage one another to carry out their evil deed.
They plan how to hide snares,
and boast, “Who will see them?”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
But God will shoot at them;
suddenly they will be wounded by an arrow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their slander will bring about their demise.
All who see them will shudder,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and all people will fear.
They will proclaim what God has done,
and reflect on his deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The godly will rejoice in the Lord
and take shelter in him.
All the morally upright will boast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise awaits you, O God, in Zion.
Vows made to you are fulfilled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You hear prayers;
all people approach you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our record of sins overwhelms me,
but you forgive our acts of rebellion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed is the one whom you choose,
and allow to live in your palace courts.
May we be satisfied with the good things of your house—
your holy palace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You answer our prayers by performing awesome acts of deliverance,
O God, our savior.
All the ends of the earth trust in you,
as well as those living across the wide seas.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You created the mountains by your power,
and demonstrated your strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You calmed the raging seas
and their roaring waves,
as well as the commotion made by the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even those living in the remotest areas are awestruck by your acts;
you cause those living in the east and west to praise you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You saturate its furrows,
and soak its plowed ground.
With rain showers you soften its soil,
and make its crops grow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crown the year with your good blessings,
and you leave abundance in your wake.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The pastures in the wilderness glisten with moisture,
and the hills are clothed with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The meadows are clothed with sheep,
and the valleys are covered with grain.
They shout joyfully, yes, they sing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shout out praise to God, all the earth!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing praises about the majesty of his reputation.
Give him the honor he deserves!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to God:
“How awesome are your deeds!
Because of your great power your enemies cower in fear before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the earth worships you
and sings praises to you.
They sing praises to your name.” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come and witness God’s exploits!
His acts on behalf of people are awesome.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Praise our God, you nations.
Loudly proclaim his praise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He preserves our lives
and does not allow our feet to slip.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you, O God, tested us;
you purified us like refined silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You led us into a trap;
you caused us to suffer.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will enter your temple with burnt sacrifices;
I will fulfill the vows I made to you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
which my lips uttered
and my mouth spoke when I was in trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will offer up to you fattened animals as burnt sacrifices,
along with the smell of sacrificial rams.
I will offer cattle and goats. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come! Listen, all you who are loyal to God.
I will declare what he has done for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I cried out to him for help
and praised him with my tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had harbored sin in my heart,
the Lord would not have listened.
speaker: Narrator

text:
However, God heard;
he listened to my prayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God deserves praise,
for he did not reject my prayer
or abandon his love for me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God show us his favor and bless us.
May he smile on us. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then those living on earth will know what you are like;
all nations will know how you deliver your people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the nations thank you, O God.
Let all the nations thank you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let foreigners rejoice and celebrate.
For you execute justice among the nations,
and govern the people living on earth. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the nations thank you, O God.
Let all the nations thank you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The earth yields its crops.
May God, our God, bless us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May God bless us.
Then all the ends of the earth will give him the honor he deserves.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
As smoke is driven away by the wind, so you drive them away.
As wax melts before fire,
so the wicked are destroyed before God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Sing to God! Sing praises to his name.
Exalt the one who rides on the clouds.
For the Lord is his name.
Rejoice before him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is a father to the fatherless
and an advocate for widows.
God rules from his holy dwelling place.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
O God, when you lead your people into battle,
when you march through the wastelands, (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
the earth shakes.
Yes, the heavens pour down rain
before God, the God of Sinai,
before God, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you cause abundant showers to fall on your chosen people.
When they are tired, you sustain them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for you live among them.
You sustain the oppressed with your good blessings, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord speaks;
many, many women spread the good news.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Kings leading armies run away—they run away!
The lovely lady of the house divides up the loot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you lie down among the sheepfolds,
the wings of the dove are covered with silver
and with glittering gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Sovereign One scatters kings,
let it snow on Zalmon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountain of Bashan is a towering mountain;
the mountain of Bashan is a mountain with many peaks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you look with envy, O mountains with many peaks,
at the mountain where God has decided to live?
Indeed the Lord will live there permanently.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You ascend on high;
you have taken many captives.
You receive tribute from men,
including even sinful rebels.
Indeed, the Lord God lives there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord deserves praise.
Day after day he carries our burden,
the God who delivers us. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Our God is a God who delivers;
the Lord, the Sovereign Lord, can rescue from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, God strikes the heads of his enemies,
the hairy foreheads of those who persist in rebellion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says,
“I will retrieve them from Bashan.
I will bring them back from the depths of the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that your feet may stomp in their blood,
and your dogs may eat their portion of the enemies’ corpses.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
They see your processions, O God—
the processions of my God, my king, who marches along in holy splendor.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
In your large assemblies praise God,
the Lord, in the assemblies of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is little Benjamin, their ruler,
and the princes of Judah in their robes,
along with the princes of Zebulun and the princes of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God has decreed that you will be powerful.
O God, you who have acted on our behalf, demonstrate your power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because of your temple in Jerusalem,
kings bring tribute to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sound your battle cry against the wild beast of the reeds,
and the nations that assemble like a herd of calves led by bulls.
They humble themselves and offer gold and silver as tribute.
God scatters the nations that like to do battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They come with red cloth from Egypt.
Ethiopia voluntarily offers tribute to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O kingdoms of the earth, sing to God.
Sing praises to the Lord, (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
to the one who rides through the sky from ancient times.
Look! He thunders loudly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Acknowledge God’s power,
his sovereignty over Israel,
and the power he reveals in the skies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are awe-inspiring, O God, as you emerge from your holy temple.
It is the God of Israel who gives the people power and strength.
God deserves praise!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deliver me, O God,
for the water has reached my neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I sink into the deep mire
where there is no solid ground;
I am in deep water,
and the current overpowers me.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Those who hate me without cause
are more numerous than the hairs of my head.
Those who want to destroy me,
my enemies for no reason,
outnumber me.
They make me repay what I did not steal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you are aware of my foolish sins;
my guilt is not hidden from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let none who rely on you be disgraced because of me,
O Sovereign Lord of Heaven’s Armies.
Let none who seek you be ashamed because of me,
O God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I suffer humiliation for your sake
and am thoroughly disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My own brothers treat me like a stranger;
they act as if I were a foreigner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly zeal for your house consumes me;
I endure the insults of those who insult you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I weep and refrain from eating food,
which causes others to insult me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I wear sackcloth
and they ridicule me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who sit at the city gate gossip about me;
drunkards mock me in their songs.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, may you hear my prayer and be favorably disposed to me.
O God, because of your great loyal love,
answer me with your faithful deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue me from the mud. Don’t let me sink.
Deliver me from those who hate me,
from the deep water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t let the current overpower me.
Don’t let the deep swallow me up.
Don’t let the Pit devour me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer me, O Lord, for your loyal love is good.
Because of your great compassion, turn toward me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not ignore your servant,
for I am in trouble. Answer me right away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come near me and redeem me.
Because of my enemies, rescue me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You know how I am insulted, humiliated, and disgraced;
you can see all my enemies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They put bitter poison into my food,
and to quench my thirst they give me vinegar to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May their dining table become a trap before them.
May it be a snare for that group of friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May their eyes be blinded.
Make them shake violently.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out your judgment on them.
May your raging anger overtake them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May their camp become desolate,
their tents uninhabited.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they harass the one whom you discipline;
they spread the news about the suffering of those whom you punish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hold them accountable for all their sins.
Do not vindicate them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May their names be deleted from the scroll of the living.
Do not let their names be listed with the godly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am oppressed and suffering.
O God, deliver and protect me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will sing praises to God’s name.
I will magnify him as I give him thanks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That will please the Lord more than an ox or a bull
with horns and hooves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The oppressed look on—let them rejoice.
You who seek God, may you be encouraged.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord listens to the needy;
he does not despise his captive people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the heavens and the earth praise him,
along with the seas and everything that swims in them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God will deliver Zion
and rebuild the cities of Judah,
and his people will again live in them and possess Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of his servants will inherit it,
and those who are loyal to him will live in it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, please be willing to rescue me.
O Lord, hurry and help me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May those who are trying to take my life
be embarrassed and ashamed.
May those who want to harm me
be turned back and ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May those who say, “Aha! Aha!”
be driven back and disgraced.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May all those who seek you be happy and rejoice in you.
May those who love to experience your deliverance say continually,
“May God be praised!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am oppressed and needy.
O God, hurry to me.
You are my helper and my deliverer.
O Lord, do not delay.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In you, O Lord, I have taken shelter.
Never let me be humiliated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Vindicate me by rescuing me.
Listen to me. Deliver me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be my protector and refuge,
a stronghold where I can be safe.
For you are my high ridge and my stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My God, rescue me from the power of the wicked,
from the hand of the cruel oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you are my hope;
O Sovereign Lord, I have trusted in you since I was young.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Many are appalled when they see me,
but you are my secure shelter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I praise you constantly
and speak of your splendor all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not reject me in my old age.
When my strength fails, do not abandon me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my enemies talk about me;
those waiting for a chance to kill me plot my demise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “God has abandoned him.
Run and seize him, for there is no one who will rescue him.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, do not remain far away from me.
My God, hurry and help me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May my accusers be humiliated and defeated.
May those who want to harm me be covered with scorn and disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, I will wait continually,
and will continue to praise you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will tell about your justice,
and all day long proclaim your salvation,
though I cannot fathom its full extent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will come and tell about the mighty acts of the Sovereign Lord.
I will proclaim your justice—yours alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, you have taught me since I was young,
and I am still declaring your amazing deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even when I am old and gray,
O God, do not abandon me,
until I tell the next generation about your strength,
and those coming after me about your power.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Though you have allowed me to experience much trouble and distress,
revive me once again.
Bring me up once again from the depths of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Raise me to a position of great honor.
Turn and comfort me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will express my thanks to you with a stringed instrument,
praising your faithfulness, O my God.
I will sing praises to you accompanied by a harp,
O Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My lips will shout for joy. Yes, I will sing your praises.
I will praise you when you rescue me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All day long my tongue will also tell about your justice,
for those who want to harm me will be embarrassed and ashamed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, grant the king the ability to make just decisions.
Grant the king’s son the ability to make fair decisions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he will judge your people fairly,
and your oppressed ones equitably.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mountains will bring news of peace to the people,
and the hills will announce justice.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
People will fear you as long as the sun and moon remain in the sky,
for generation after generation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will descend like rain on the mown grass,
like showers that drench the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
During his days the godly will flourish;
peace will prevail as long as the moon remains in the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he rule from sea to sea,
and from the Euphrates River to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before him the coastlands will bow down,
and his enemies will lick the dust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The kings of Tarshish and the coastlands will offer gifts;
the kings of Sheba and Seba will bring tribute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All kings will bow down to him;
all nations will serve him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he will rescue the needy when they cry out for help,
and the oppressed who have no defender.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will take pity on the poor and needy;
the lives of the needy he will save.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From harm and violence he will defend them;
he will value their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May he live! May they offer him gold from Sheba.
May they continually pray for him.
May they pronounce blessings on him all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May there be an abundance of grain in the earth;
on the tops of the mountains may it sway.
May its fruit trees flourish like the forests of Lebanon.
May its crops be as abundant as the grass of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May his fame endure.
May his dynasty last as long as the sun remains in the sky.
May they use his name when they formulate their blessings.
May all nations consider him to be favored by God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord God, the God of Israel, deserves praise.
He alone accomplishes amazing things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His glorious name deserves praise forevermore.
May his majestic splendor fill the whole earth.
We agree! We agree!
speaker: Narrator

text: This collection of the prayers of David son of Jesse ends here.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly God is good to Israel,
and to those whose motives are pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, my feet almost slipped;
my feet almost slid out from under me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I envied those who are proud,
as I observed the prosperity of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they suffer no pain;
their bodies are strong and well fed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are immune to the trouble common to men;
they do not suffer as other men do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arrogance is their necklace,
and violence covers them like clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their prosperity causes them to do wrong;
their thoughts are sinful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They mock and say evil things;
they proudly threaten violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They speak as if they rule in heaven,
and lay claim to the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore they have more than enough food to eat,
and even suck up the water of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “How does God know what we do?
Is the Most High aware of what goes on?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take a good look. This is what the wicked are like,
those who always have it so easy and get richer and richer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I concluded, “Surely in vain I have kept my motives pure
and maintained a pure lifestyle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I suffer all day long,
and am punished every morning.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
If I had publicized these thoughts,
I would have betrayed your people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I tried to make sense of this,
it was troubling to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I entered the precincts of God’s temple,
and understood the destiny of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely you put them in slippery places;
you bring them down to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How desolate they become in a mere moment.
Terrifying judgments make their demise complete.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are like a dream after one wakes up.
O Lord, when you awake you will despise them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, my spirit was bitter,
and my insides felt sharp pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I was ignorant and lacked insight;
I was as senseless as an animal before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I am continually with you;
you hold my right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You guide me by your wise advice,
and then you will lead me to a position of honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whom do I have in heaven but you?
On earth there is no one I desire but you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My flesh and my heart may grow weak,
but God always protects my heart and gives me stability.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, look! Those far from you die;
you destroy everyone who is unfaithful to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But as for me, God’s presence is all I need.
I have made the Sovereign Lord my shelter,
as I declare all the things you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why, O God, have you permanently rejected us?
Why does your anger burn against the sheep of your pasture?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your people whom you acquired in ancient times,
whom you rescued so they could be your very own nation,
as well as Mount Zion, where you dwell.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hurry to the permanent ruins,
and to all the damage the enemy has done to the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your enemies roar in the middle of your sanctuary;
they set up their battle flags.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They invade like lumberjacks
swinging their axes in a thick forest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now they are tearing down all its engravings
with axes and crowbars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They set your sanctuary on fire;
they desecrate your dwelling place by knocking it to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say to themselves,
“We will oppress all of them.”
They burn down all the places in the land where people worship God.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
How long, O God, will the adversary hurl insults?
Will the enemy blaspheme your name forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why do you remain inactive?
Intervene and destroy him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But God has been my king from ancient times,
performing acts of deliverance on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You destroyed the sea by your strength;
you shattered the heads of the sea monster in the water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crushed the heads of Leviathan;
you fed him to the people who live along the coast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You broke open the spring and the stream;
you dried up perpetually flowing rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You established the cycle of day and night;
you put the moon and sun in place.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You set up all the boundaries of the earth;
you created the cycle of summer and winter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember how the enemy hurls insults, O Lord,
and how a foolish nation blasphemes your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not hand the life of your dove over to a wild animal.
Do not continue to disregard the lives of your oppressed people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember your covenant promises,
for the dark regions of the earth are full of places where violence rules.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let the afflicted be turned back in shame.
Let the oppressed and poor praise your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise up, O God. Defend your honor.
Remember how fools insult you all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not disregard what your enemies say,
or the unceasing shouts of those who defy you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God says,
“At the appointed times,
I judge fairly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the earth and all its inhabitants dissolve in fear,
I make its pillars secure.” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
I say to the proud, “Do not be proud,”
and to the wicked, “Do not be so confident of victory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be so certain you have won.
Do not speak with your head held so high.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For victory does not come from the east or west,
or from the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For God is the judge.
He brings one down and exalts another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord holds in his hand a cup
full of foaming wine mixed with spices,
and pours it out.
Surely all the wicked of the earth
will slurp it up and drink it to its very last drop.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, I will continually tell what you have done;
I will sing praises to the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God has revealed himself in Judah;
in Israel his reputation is great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lives in Salem;
he dwells in Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There he shattered the arrows,
the shield, the sword, and the rest of the weapons of war. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
You shine brightly and reveal your majesty,
as you descend from the hills where you killed your prey.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
At the sound of your battle cry, O God of Jacob,
both rider and horse “fell asleep.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are awesome! Yes, you!
Who can withstand your intense anger?
speaker: Narrator

text:
From heaven you announced what their punishment would be.
The earth was afraid and silent
speaker: Narrator

text:
when God arose to execute judgment,
and to deliver all the oppressed of the earth. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly your angry judgment upon men will bring you praise;
you reveal your anger in full measure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make vows to the Lord your God and repay them.
Let all those who surround him bring tribute to the awesome one.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He humbles princes;
the kings of the earth regard him as awesome.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will cry out to God and call for help.
I will cry out to God and he will pay attention to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my time of trouble I sought the Lord.
I kept my hand raised in prayer throughout the night.
I refused to be comforted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, “I will remember God while I groan;
I will think about him while my strength leaves me.” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
You held my eyelids open;
I was troubled and could not speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I thought about the days of old,
about ancient times.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I asked, “Will the Lord reject me forever?
Will he never again show me his favor?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has his loyal love disappeared forever?
Has his promise failed forever?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Has God forgotten to be merciful?
Has his anger stifled his compassion?” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “I am sickened by the thought
that the Most High might become inactive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will remember the works of the Lord.
Yes, I will remember the amazing things you did long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will think about all you have done;
I will reflect upon your deeds.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, your deeds are extraordinary.
What god can compare to our great God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are the God who does amazing things;
you have revealed your strength among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You delivered your people by your strength—
the children of Jacob and Joseph. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
The waters saw you, O God,
the waters saw you and trembled.
Yes, the depths of the sea shook with fear.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
You led your people like a flock of sheep,
by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay attention, my people, to my instruction.
Listen to the words I speak.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will sing a song that imparts wisdom;
I will make insightful observations about the past.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What we have heard and learned—
that which our ancestors have told us—
speaker: Narrator

text:
we will not hide from their descendants.
We will tell the next generation
about the Lord’s praiseworthy acts,
about his strength and the amazing things he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He established a rule in Jacob;
he set up a law in Israel.
He commanded our ancestors
to make his deeds known to their descendants,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that the next generation, children yet to be born,
might know about them.
They will grow up and tell their descendants about them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will place their confidence in God.
They will not forget the works of God,
and they will obey his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will not be like their ancestors,
who were a stubborn and rebellious generation,
a generation that was not committed
and faithful to God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Ephraimites were armed with bows,
but they retreated in the day of battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They did not keep their covenant with God,
and they refused to obey his law.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They forgot what he had done,
the amazing things he had shown them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He did amazing things in the sight of their ancestors,
in the land of Egypt, in the region of Zoan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He divided the sea and led them across it;
he made the water stand in a heap.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He led them with a cloud by day,
and with the light of a fire all night long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He broke open rocks in the wilderness,
and gave them enough water to fill the depths of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He caused streams to flow from the rock,
and made the water flow like rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet they continued to sin against him,
and rebelled against the Most High in the desert.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They willfully challenged God
by asking for food to satisfy their appetite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They insulted God, saying,
“Is God really able to give us food in the wilderness?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, he struck a rock and water flowed out;
streams gushed forth.
But can he also give us food?
Will he provide meat for his people?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the Lord heard this, he was furious.
A fire broke out against Jacob,
and his anger flared up against Israel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
because they did not have faith in God,
and did not trust his ability to deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gave a command to the clouds above,
and opened the doors in the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained down manna for them to eat;
he gave them the grain of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Man ate the food of the mighty ones.
He sent them more than enough to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought the east wind through the sky,
and by his strength led forth the south wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained down meat on them like dust,
birds as numerous as the sand on the seashores.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He caused them to fall right in the middle of their camp,
all around their homes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They ate until they were beyond full;
he gave them what they desired.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were not yet filled up;
their food was still in their mouths,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Despite all this, they continued to sin,
and did not trust him to do amazing things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So he caused them to die unsatisfied
and filled with terror.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he struck them down, they sought his favor;
they turned back and longed for God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They remembered that God was their protector,
and that God Most High was their deliverer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they deceived him with their words,
and lied to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were not really committed to him,
and they were unfaithful to his covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he is compassionate.
He forgives sin and does not destroy.
He often holds back his anger,
and does not stir up his fury.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He remembered that they were made of flesh,
and were like a wind that blows past and does not return.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How often they rebelled against him in the wilderness,
and insulted him in the wastelands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They again challenged God,
and offended the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They did not remember what he had done,
how he delivered them from the enemy,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he performed his awesome deeds in Egypt,
and his acts of judgment in the region of Zoan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He turned their rivers into blood,
and they could not drink from their streams.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He sent swarms of biting insects against them,
as well as frogs that overran their land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He gave their crops to the grasshopper,
the fruit of their labor to the locust.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He destroyed their vines with hail,
and their sycamore-fig trees with driving rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rained hail down on their cattle,
and hurled lightning bolts down on their livestock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His raging anger lashed out against them.
He sent fury, rage, and trouble
as messengers who bring disaster.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
He struck down all the firstborn in Egypt,
the firstfruits of their reproductive power in the tents of Ham.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he brought out his people like sheep;
he led them through the wilderness like a flock.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He guided them safely along, and they were not afraid;
but the sea covered their enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He brought them to the border of his holy land,
to this mountainous land that his right hand acquired.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Yet they challenged and defied God Most High,
and did not obey his commands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were unfaithful and acted as treacherously as their ancestors;
they were as unreliable as a malfunctioning bow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They made him angry with their pagan shrines,
and made him jealous with their idols.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God heard and was angry;
he completely rejected Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He abandoned the sanctuary at Shiloh,
the tent where he lived among men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He allowed the symbol of his strong presence to be captured;
he gave the symbol of his splendor into the hand of the enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He delivered his people over to the sword,
and was angry with his chosen nation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fire consumed their young men,
and their virgins remained unmarried.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their priests fell by the sword,
but their widows did not weep.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But then the Lord awoke from his sleep;
he was like a warrior in a drunken rage.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He drove his enemies back;
he made them a permanent target for insults.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He rejected the tent of Joseph;
he did not choose the tribe of Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose the tribe of Judah
and Mount Zion, which he loves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He made his sanctuary as enduring as the heavens above,
as secure as the earth, which he established permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He chose David, his servant,
and took him from the sheepfolds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He took him away from following the mother sheep,
and made him the shepherd of Jacob, his people,
and of Israel, his chosen nation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David cared for them with pure motives;
he led them with skill.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
They have given the corpses of your servants
to the birds of the sky,
the flesh of your loyal followers
to the beasts of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have made their blood flow like water
all around Jerusalem, and there is no one to bury them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have become an object of disdain to our neighbors;
those who live on our borders taunt and insult us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long will this go on, O Lord?
Will you stay angry forever?
How long will your rage burn like fire?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pour out your anger on the nations that do not acknowledge you,
on the kingdoms that do not pray to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they have devoured Jacob
and destroyed his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not hold us accountable for the sins of earlier generations.
Quickly send your compassion our way,
for we are in serious trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Help us, O God, our deliverer!
For the sake of your glorious reputation, rescue us.
Forgive our sins for the sake of your reputation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should the nations say, “Where is their God?”
Before our very eyes may the shed blood of your servants
be avenged among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to the painful cries of the prisoners.
Use your great strength to set free those condemned to die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pay back our neighbors in full.
May they be insulted the same way they insulted you, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then we, your people, the sheep of your pasture,
will continually thank you.
We will tell coming generations of your praiseworthy acts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Shepherd of Israel, pay attention,
you who lead Joseph like a flock of sheep.
You who sit enthroned above the cherubim, reveal your splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the sight of Ephraim, Benjamin, and Manasseh reveal your power.
Come and deliver us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, restore us.
Smile on us. Then we will be delivered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies,
how long will you remain angry at your people while they pray to you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have given them tears as food;
you have made them drink tears by the measure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have made our neighbors dislike us,
and our enemies insult us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God of Heaven’s Armies, restore us.
Smile on us. Then we will be delivered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You uprooted a vine from Egypt;
you drove out nations and transplanted it.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The mountains were covered by its shadow,
the highest cedars by its branches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Its branches reached the Mediterranean Sea,
and its shoots the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why did you break down its walls,
so that all who pass by pluck its fruit?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wild boars of the forest ruin it;
the insects of the field feed on it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God of Heaven’s Armies, come back.
Look down from heaven and take notice.
Take care of this vine,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the root your right hand planted,
the shoot you made to grow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is burned and cut down.
May those who did this die because you are displeased with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May you give support to the one you have chosen,
to the one whom you raised up for yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then we will not turn away from you.
Revive us and we will pray to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies, restore us.
Smile on us. Then we will be delivered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shout for joy to God, our source of strength!
Shout out to the God of Jacob!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing a song and play the tambourine,
the pleasant-sounding harp, and the ten-stringed instrument.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sound the ram’s horn on the day of the new moon,
and on the day of the full moon when our festival begins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For observing the festival is a requirement for Israel;
it is an ordinance given by the God of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He decreed it as a regulation in Joseph,
when he attacked the land of Egypt.
I heard a voice I did not recognize.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It said: “I removed the burden from his shoulder;
his hands were released from holding the basket.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In your distress you called out and I rescued you.
I answered you from a dark thundercloud.
I tested you at the waters of Meribah. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
I said, ‘Listen, my people!
I will warn you.
O Israel, if only you would obey me!
speaker: Narrator

text:
There must be no other god among you.
You must not worship a foreign god.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am the Lord, your God,
the one who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
Open your mouth wide and I will fill it.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
But my people did not obey me;
Israel did not submit to me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I gave them over to their stubborn desires;
they did what seemed right to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If only my people would obey me!
If only Israel would keep my commands!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I would quickly subdue their enemies,
and attack their adversaries.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
(May those who hate the Lord cower in fear before him.
May they be permanently humiliated.)
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I would feed Israel the best wheat,
and would satisfy your appetite with honey from the rocky cliffs.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
God stands in the assembly of El;
in the midst of the gods he renders judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He says, “How long will you make unjust legal decisions
and show favoritism to the wicked? (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Defend the cause of the poor and the fatherless.
Vindicate the oppressed and suffering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rescue the poor and needy.
Deliver them from the power of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They neither know nor understand.
They stumble around in the dark,
while all the foundations of the earth crumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I thought, ‘You are gods;
all of you are sons of the Most High.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet you will die like mortals;
you will fall like all the other rulers.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rise up, O God, and execute judgment on the earth!
For you own all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, do not be silent.
Do not ignore us. Do not be inactive, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For look, your enemies are making a commotion;
those who hate you are hostile.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They carefully plot against your people,
and make plans to harm the ones you cherish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They say, “Come on, let’s annihilate them so they are no longer a nation.
Then the name of Israel will be remembered no more.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, they devise a unified strategy;
they form an alliance against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It includes the tents of Edom and the Ishmaelites,
Moab and the Hagrites,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gebal, Ammon, and Amalek,
Philistia and the inhabitants of Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even Assyria has allied with them,
lending its strength to the descendants of Lot. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do to them as you did to Midian—
as you did to Sisera and Jabin at the Kishon River.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They were destroyed at Endor;
their corpses were like manure on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make their nobles like Oreb and Zeeb,
and all their rulers like Zebah and Zalmunna,
speaker: Narrator

text: who said, “Let’s take over the pastures of God.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
O my God, make them like dead thistles,
like dead weeds blown away by the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the fire that burns down the forest,
or the flames that consume the mountainsides,
speaker: Narrator

text:
chase them with your gale winds,
and terrify them with your windstorm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cover their faces with shame,
so they might seek you, O Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May they be humiliated and continually terrified.
May they die in shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will know that you alone are the Lord,
the Most High over all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How lovely is the place where you live,
O Lord of Heaven’s Armies!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I desperately want to be
in the courts of the Lord’s temple.
My heart and my entire being shout for joy
to the living God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even the birds find a home there,
and the swallow builds a nest,
where she can protect her young
near your altars, O Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
my King and my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed are those who live in your temple
and praise you continually. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed are those who find their strength in you,
and long to travel the roads that lead to your temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As they pass through the Baca Valley,
he provides a spring for them.
The rain even covers it with pools of water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are sustained as they travel along;
each one appears before God in Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies,
hear my prayer.
Listen, O God of Jacob. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, take notice of our shield.
Show concern for your chosen king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly spending just one day in your temple courts is better
than spending a thousand elsewhere.
I would rather stand at the entrance to the temple of my God
than live in the tents of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
O Lord of Heaven’s Armies,
how blessed are those who trust in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, you showed favor to your land;
you restored the well-being of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You pardoned the wrongdoing of your people;
you forgave all their sin. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
You withdrew all your fury;
you turned back from your raging anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Restore us, O God our deliverer.
Do not be displeased with us.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you stay mad at us forever?
Will you remain angry throughout future generations?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Will you not revive us once more?
Then your people will rejoice in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, show us your loyal love.
Bestow on us your deliverance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will listen to what God the Lord says.
For he will make peace with his people, his faithful followers.
Yet they must not return to their foolish ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly his loyal followers will soon experience his deliverance;
then his splendor will again appear in our land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Loyal love and faithfulness meet;
deliverance and peace greet each other with a kiss.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Faithfulness grows from the ground,
and deliverance looks down from the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, the Lord will bestow his good blessings,
and our land will yield its crops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deliverance goes before him,
and prepares a pathway for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, O Lord. Answer me.
For I am oppressed and needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Protect me, for I am loyal.
You are my God; deliver your servant who trusts in you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have mercy on me, O Lord,
for I cry out to you all day long.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make your servant glad,
for to you, O Lord, I pray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly, O Lord, you are kind and forgiving,
and show great faithfulness to all who cry out to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, hear my prayer.
Pay attention to my plea for mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In my time of trouble I cry out to you,
for you will answer me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
None can compare to you among the gods, O Lord.
Your exploits are incomparable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the nations, whom you created,
will come and worship you, O Lord.
They will honor your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you are great and do amazing things.
You alone are God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, teach me how you want me to live.
Then I will obey your commands.
Make me wholeheartedly committed to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, my God, I will give you thanks with my whole heart.
I will honor your name continually.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you will extend your great loyal love to me,
and will deliver my life from the depths of Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O God, arrogant men attack me;
a gang of ruthless men, who do not respect you, seek my life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you, O Lord, are a compassionate and merciful God.
You are patient and demonstrate great loyal love and faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn toward me and have mercy on me.
Give your servant your strength.
Deliver this son of your female servant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Show me evidence of your favor.
Then those who hate me will see it and be ashamed,
for you, O Lord, will help me and comfort me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord’s city is in the holy hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord loves the gates of Zion
more than all the dwelling places of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People say wonderful things about you,
O city of God. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
I mention Rahab and Babylon to my followers.
Here are Philistia and Tyre, along with Ethiopia.
It is said of them, “This one was born there.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But it is said of Zion’s residents,
“Each one of these was born in her,
and the Most High makes her secure.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord writes in the census book of the nations,
“This one was born there.” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for the singers, as well as the pipers—
all of them sing within your walls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God who delivers me,
by day I cry out
and at night I pray before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to my prayer.
Pay attention to my cry for help.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my life is filled with troubles,
and I am ready to enter Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They treat me like those who descend into the grave.
I am like a helpless man,
speaker: Narrator

text:
adrift among the dead,
like corpses lying in the grave,
whom you remember no more,
and who are cut off from your power.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You place me in the lowest regions of the Pit,
in the dark places, in the watery depths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your anger bears down on me,
and you overwhelm me with all your waves. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
Do you accomplish amazing things for the dead?
Do the departed spirits rise up and give you thanks? (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Is your loyal love proclaimed in the grave,
or your faithfulness in the place of the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Are your amazing deeds experienced in the dark region,
or your deliverance in the land of oblivion?
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for me, I cry out to you, O Lord;
in the morning my prayer confronts you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, why do you reject me,
and pay no attention to me?
speaker: Narrator

text:
I am oppressed and have been on the verge of death since my youth.
I have been subjected to your horrors and am numb with pain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your anger overwhelms me;
your terrors destroy me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They surround me like water all day long;
they join forces and encircle me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You cause my friends and neighbors to keep their distance;
those who know me leave me alone in the darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will sing continually about the Lord’s faithful deeds;
to future generations I will proclaim your faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For I say, “Loyal love is permanently established;
in the skies you set up your faithfulness.”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
‘I will give you an eternal dynasty
and establish your throne throughout future generations.’” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord, the heavens praise your amazing deeds,
as well as your faithfulness in the angelic assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For who in the skies can compare to the Lord?
Who is like the Lord among the heavenly beings,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a God who is honored in the great angelic assembly,
and more awesome than all who surround him?
speaker: Narrator

text:
O Lord God of Heaven’s Armies!
Who is strong like you, O Lord?
Your faithfulness surrounds you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You rule over the proud sea.
When its waves surge, you calm them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You crushed the Proud One and killed it;
with your strong arm you scattered your enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heavens belong to you, as does the earth.
You made the world and all it contains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You created the north and the south.
Tabor and Hermon rejoice in your name.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your arm is powerful,
your hand strong,
your right hand victorious.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Equity and justice are the foundation of your throne.
Loyal love and faithfulness characterize your rule.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How blessed are the people who worship you!
O Lord, they experience your favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They rejoice in your name all day long,
and are vindicated by your justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you give them splendor and strength.
By your favor we are victorious.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For our shield belongs to the Lord,
our king to the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I have discovered David, my servant.
With my holy oil I have anointed him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My hand will support him,
and my arm will strengthen him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No enemy will be able to exact tribute from him;
a violent oppressor will not be able to humiliate him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will crush his enemies before him;
I will strike down those who hate him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will experience my faithfulness and loyal love,
and by my name he will win victories.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will place his hand over the sea,
his right hand over the rivers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will call out to me,
‘You are my father, my God, and the protector who delivers me.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will appoint him to be my firstborn son,
the most exalted of the earth’s kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will always extend my loyal love to him,
and my covenant with him is secure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will give him an eternal dynasty,
and make his throne as enduring as the skies above.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If his sons reject my law
and disobey my regulations,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if they break my rules
and do not keep my commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will punish their rebellion by beating them with a club,
their sin by inflicting them with bruises.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But I will not remove my loyal love from him,
nor be unfaithful to my promise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will not break my covenant
or go back on what I promised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Once and for all I have vowed by my own holiness,
I will never deceive David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His dynasty will last forever.
His throne will endure before me, like the sun;
speaker: Narrator

text:
it will remain stable, like the moon.
His throne will endure like the skies.” (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
But you have spurned and rejected him;
you are angry with your chosen king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have repudiated your covenant with your servant;
you have thrown his crown to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have broken down all his walls;
you have made his strongholds a heap of ruins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All who pass by have robbed him;
he has become an object of disdain to his neighbors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have allowed his adversaries to be victorious,
and all his enemies to rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You turn back his sword from the adversary,
and have not sustained him in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have brought to an end his splendor,
and have knocked his throne to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have cut short his youth,
and have covered him with shame. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long, O Lord, will this last?
Will you remain hidden forever?
Will your anger continue to burn like fire?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take note of my brief lifespan.
Why do you make all people so mortal?
speaker: Narrator

text:
No man can live on without experiencing death,
or deliver his life from the power of Sheol. (Selah)
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where are your earlier faithful deeds, O Lord,
the ones performed in accordance with your reliable oath to David?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take note, O Lord, of the way your servants are taunted,
and of how I must bear so many insults from people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your enemies, O Lord, hurl insults;
they insult your chosen king as they dog his footsteps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord deserves praise forevermore!
We agree! We agree!
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, you have been our protector through all generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even before the mountains came into existence,
or you brought the world into being,
you were the eternal God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You make mankind return to the dust,
and say, “Return, O people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, in your eyes a thousand years
are like yesterday that quickly passes,
or like one of the divisions of the nighttime.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You bring their lives to an end and they “fall asleep.”
In the morning they are like the grass that sprouts up:
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the morning it glistens and sprouts up;
at evening time it withers and dries up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, we are consumed by your anger;
we are terrified by your wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You are aware of our sins;
you even know about our hidden sins.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yes, throughout all our days we experience your raging fury;
the years of our lives pass quickly, like a sigh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The days of our lives add up to seventy years,
or eighty, if one is especially strong.
But even one’s best years are marred by trouble and oppression.
Yes, they pass quickly and we fly away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can really fathom the intensity of your anger?
Your raging fury causes people to fear you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So teach us to consider our mortality,
so that we might live wisely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Turn back toward us, O Lord.
How long must this suffering last?
Have pity on your servants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Satisfy us in the morning with your loyal love.
Then we will shout for joy and be happy all our days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make us happy in proportion to the days you have afflicted us,
in proportion to the years we have experienced trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May your servants see your work.
May their sons see your majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
May our Sovereign God extend his favor to us.
Make our endeavors successful.
Yes, make them successful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As for you, the one who lives in the shelter of the Most High,
and resides in the protective shadow of the Sovereign One—
speaker: Narrator

text:
I say this about the Lord, my shelter and my stronghold,
my God in whom I trust—
speaker: Narrator

text:
he will certainly rescue you from the snare of the hunter
and from the destructive plague.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
You need not fear the terrors of the night,
the arrow that flies by day,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the plague that stalks in the darkness,
or the disease that ravages at noon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Though a thousand may fall beside you,
and a multitude on your right side,
it will not reach you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Certainly you will see it with your very own eyes—
you will see the wicked paid back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you have taken refuge in the Lord,
my shelter, the Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No harm will overtake you;
no illness will come near your home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For he will order his angels
to protect you in all you do.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will lift you up in their hands,
so you will not slip and fall on a stone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will subdue a lion and a snake;
you will trample underfoot a young lion and a serpent.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will satisfy him with long life,
and will let him see my salvation.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is fitting to thank the Lord,
and to sing praises to your name, O Most High.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is fitting to proclaim your loyal love in the morning,
and your faithfulness during the night,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to the accompaniment of a ten-stringed instrument and a lyre,
to the accompaniment of the meditative tone of the harp.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For you, O Lord, have made me happy by your work.
I will sing for joy because of what you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How great are your works, O Lord!
Your plans are very intricate!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The spiritually insensitive do not recognize this;
the fool does not understand this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked sprout up like grass,
and all the evildoers glisten,
it is so that they may be annihilated.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you, O Lord, reign forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, look at your enemies, O Lord.
Indeed, look at how your enemies perish.
All the evildoers are scattered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You exalt my horn like that of a wild ox.
